outPerfoms.factdes: The historic China-Canada Dinosaur Project (1986 - 1991) cost roughly $11 million USD over the course of 6 years, though only resulting in 11 new dinosaur species.
outPerfoms.p1: Nueva especie de dinosaurio por 5.000 dólares en lugar de hasta 500.000 dólares
outPerfoms.p2: En EE. UU. y Europa, una campaña de 150.000 dólares podría descubrir uno o dos especímenes de interés científico, generalmente de especies conocidas.
outPerfoms.p3: En la Patagonia, 5.000 dólares financian una campaña que a menudo da como resultado descubrimientos pioneros a nivel mundial, publicados en las revistas más prestigiosas, y que reescriben la historia paleontológica.

hero.subtitle_line2: With the Highest Success Rate in the World
hero.lead: Our team’s deep expertise and the richness of potential discoveries in Patagonia (where fossils often lie above ground) have allowed for a 70-80% success rate in finding new species or major discoveries with every excavation.

statement.text: Every $5,000 EXCAVATION we EXECUTE has a 70–80% chance of yielding NEW SPECIES or ground-breaking DISCOVERIES!

maip.label: Discovery highlight #1
maip.title: Maip macrothorax
maip.subtitle: The Largest Megaraptor Ever Discovered
maip.p1: In 2019, near El Calafate in Patagonia, our team uncovered the remains of a predator unlike any seen before: Maip macrothorax.
maip.p2: At 10 meters (33 feet) long and over five tons, with claws up to 40 cm (16 in), it was built for lethal speed and power.
maip.p3: Nicknamed the “Shadow of Death,” Maip was named after an Aonikenk spirit said to kill with icy winds. Its second name, macrothorax, reflects its enormous 1.2-meter-wide chest cavity. Unlike the bulky T. Rex, Maip was lightweight, agile, and fast, making it the apex predator of southern Patagonia about 70 million years ago.
maip.p4: The discovery helped solve key mysteries about megaraptors — a family of carnivores spread across South America, Asia, and Australia — and revealed one of the largest and southernmost megaraptors ever found.

notob.label: Discovery highlight #2
notob.title: Notobatrachus
notob.subtitle: 161-Million-Year-Old Tadpole
notob.tag: Discovered By Accident During a Game
notob.p1: In the Jurassic wetlands of Patagonia, our team uncovered the world’s oldest known tadpole fossil, preserved for over 161 million years. Measuring 16 cm (6 in), this giant tadpole belonged to Notobatrachus degiustoi, an extinct frog that lived alongside dinosaurs.
notob.p2: The skeleton includes the skull, neck and back vertebrae, nearly complete arms, hind legs, and ribs—a treasure trove that allows scientists to reconstruct its power in extraordinary detail. Taurovenator’s neck was reinforced with extra bone connections, giving it the strength to hold up a colossal 1.3-meter skull with horn-like crests above its eyes.
notob.p3: What makes the discovery even more remarkable is the way it happened. After a long day of digging for dinosaurs, members of our team were relaxing and tossing rocks when one noticed a stone with a strange imprint. That “funny-looking rock” turned out to be a scientific treasure: a 161-million-year-old tadpole, pushing back evidence of frog metamorphosis by more than 30 million years.
notob.p4: The story highlights the richness of Patagonia’s fossil beds — a place where even casual moments can lead to world-changing discoveries.

patago.label: Discovery highlight #3
patago.title: Taurovenator Violantei
patago.subtitle: The Patagonian Rival to Tyrannosaurus Rex
patago.p1: In the badlands of Patagonia, our team unearthed one of the most complete skeletons ever found of a giant South American predator: Taurovenator violantei, the “Bull Hunter.” Measuring 11 meters (36 feet) in length and weighing around five tons, this dinosaur stood among the top hunters of its time, a true rival to Tyrannosaurus rex
patago.p2: This discovery proved that monotremes — the egg-laying mammals that include today’s platypus and echidna — lived in South America far earlier than once believed (alongside dinosaurs). Previously, scientists thought they came only from Australia after the dinosaurs’ extinction.
patago.p3: Living 90 million years ago, this predator ruled the forests of Gondwana. Its discovery in the Pueblo Blanco Reserve (Río Negro) cements Patagonia as one of the world’s richest fossil frontiers and showcases the fearsome diversity of apex predators that once stalked the southern continents.
patago.p4: This single tooth didn’t just add to Patagonia’s fossil record — it rewrote the evolutionary history of monotremes, revealing that the ancestor of today’s platypus was Patagonian.

impact.title: Science Community Impact
impact.description: With over 200 outreach initiatives between 2005 and 2025, our team has made science accessible to the public and contributed to educational development.
impact.bullet1: 50+ talks and lectures delivered in schools, universities, and cultural events.
impact.bullet2: 11 workshops and training sessions for teachers and professionals on innovative tools for teaching paleontology.
impact.bullet3: 12 articles published in renowned outlets, including National Geographic and specialized magazines.
impact.bullet4: Broad media presence: documentaries, television appearances on Canal Encuentro (Argentina), NHK (Japan), National Geographic Kids (USA), and Paka Paka (Argentina).
impact.bullet5: 100+ news features across international media in multiple languages.
impact.bullet6: 3 books published on paleontology and its history, with a fourth one currently in production about the dinosaurs of Patagonia.
impact.bullet7: 50+ life-sized skeletal replicas created for museums in Japan, the United States, Chile, and Argentina.

about.hero: world-class discoveries at 1/30th - 1/100th the cost with the highest success rate in the world
about.antartida: We have signed an exclusive five-year agreement with the Argentine government to conduct paleontological expeditions in Antarctica (2027–2032) in partnership with the Argentine Antarctic Institute and CONICET.
about.newDino: Uncover new dinosaur fossils that have lived 70 million years ago on the frozen continent
about.whoP1: APASUR is a nonprofit paleontological NGO based in Argentina. For over 20 years, we have carried out excavations in Patagonia, the Andes, and Antarctica—recovering, studying, and sharing the fossil heritage of South America.
about.whoP2: APASUR (La Asociación Paleontológica del Sur) is a non-profit organization created by the team of paleontologists and professionals from (LACEV-MACN) Laboratorio de Anatomía Comparada y Evolución de los Vertebrados del Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales.
about.whoP3: Its creation responds to the need for research promotion, investigation, public communication, and conservation projects for the paleontological heritage of Argentina and South America.
about.teamP1: We are one of the top Paleontology teams in Argentina, consisting of 11+ researchers, 5+ professional technicians, 2+ education & science communicators, and 10+ students based in Bernardino Rivadavia Musuem of Natural Science (Buenos Aires).
about.teamP3: With more than 400+ research papers published in national & international journals and 20+ years of experience, our team has discovered and named more than 26% of new dinosaur species in South American between 2005 - 2025.
about.teamP2: Over the years, we’ve discovered and named 33 dinosaur species in Argentina (22% of all known species in the country), plus 5 in Antarctica and other parts of Latin America. We’ve published 400+ papers and appeared 5 times on the cover of Nature.
about.excavationP1: 70-80% of our excavation campaigns resulted in new dinosaur species or breakthrough discoveries.
about.antarcticaP1: In partnership with the Argentine Antarctic Institute and CONICET, we’ve launched a long-term project to uncover dinosaur fossils near the James Ross Basin, under extreme conditions and with logistical support from scientific bases.
about.antarcticaMission: To excavate key fossil-bearing outcrops and analyze the fauna that lived on the frozen continent 70 million years ago.
about.impactP1: Beyond science, we share our discoveries with rural schools, museums, and the public. We design exhibitions, give talks, and create educational material.
about.impactP2: Our work inspires future scientists and raises awareness about Argentina’s fossil heritage.

mainSection.titleEnd: as we search for new dinosaurs in Patagonia
mainSection.intro: We are a team of paleontologists, professors, students, and naturalists part of the Laboratory of Comparative Anatomy and Evolution of Vertebrates (LACEV).

partners.title: Press & Partners
partners.alt: Logos of our press mentions and collaborating institutions

welcome.title: Filling the missing pages of evolution,
welcome.titleHighlight: one fossil at a time — in Patagonia.
welcome.p1: We are a team of paleontologists, professors, students, and naturalists part of the Laboratory of Comparative Anatomy and Evolution of Vertebrates (LACEV).
welcome.p2: For more than 20 years, we have been searching, extracting, preparing, researching, and publicly communicating paleontology in Patagonia,
welcome.p4: discovering 26% of new dinosaur species in South America.
welcome.p3: We’ve discovered 26% of new dinosaur species in South America.

hero.title: Be part of history.
hero.description: We will stream live from Río Negro, Argentina, as our team searches for new dinosaur species. For the first time, you’ll witness a real-time dig: every bone, every find, while directly supporting one of the most innovative paleontology campaigns in the world.
hero.quote: With over 40 species discovered, our team leads Paleontology in South America.

urgency.suffix: to enter the original fossil giveaway!

goal.title: 20+ years of discoveries that open new paths

desc.p1: We are 11 researchers, 5 professional technicians, 2 educators/science communicators, and 10+ students based at the Argentine Museum of Natural Sciences (Buenos Aires). We’ve achieved 5 Nature covers and 400+ scientific publications.
desc.p2: Over the past two decades we discovered and named 33 new dinosaur species in Argentina (22% of the country’s known species) plus 5 additional species in Antarctica, Brazil, Chile, and Ecuador. We also described 20+ other Mesozoic vertebrates (mammals, marine reptiles, crocodiles, turtles, and more).
desc.p3: Highlights: Maip macrothorax (a 10 m predator with a claw over 30 cm), Patagorhynchus (the oldest South American platypus), a near-complete skeleton of Taurovenator violantei, and the world’s oldest tadpole. Supported by organizations such as National Geographic (4), The Explorers Club (3), and Jurassic Foundation (3).

methods.title: How we work in the field
methods.intro: A full cycle: from prospecting to peer-reviewed science and outreach.

1.title: Prospecting
1.copy: Stratigraphy reading, mapping and systematic surveys to locate fossils.

2.title: Excavation
2.copy: Recording, plaster jacketing and safe extraction of the material.

3.title: Laboratory
3.copy: Fine prep, CT scans and comparisons with reference collections.

4.title: Publication & outreach
4.copy: Formal description, peer review and public engagement in schools, media and museums.

maip.title: Maip macrothorax
maip.copy: A ~10 m predator from the southern tip, with a >30 cm killing claw.

platypus.title: Patagorhynchus
platypus.copy: The oldest platypus found in South America, 70 million years old.

tauro.title: Taurovenator violantei
tauro.copy: Near-complete skeleton of a giant carnivore, a rival to T. rex.

tadpole.title: The oldest tadpole
tadpole.copy: A unique specimen from Patagonia, over 200 million years old.

antarctica.title: Antarctica Mission 2027–2032
antarctica.copy: Five-year agreement with the Argentine Antarctic Institute and CONICET. Goal: uncover ~70 Ma dinosaurs in the frozen continent.
antarctica.m2: Focused campaigns and extraction of promising matrices.

compliance.title: Permits & transparency
compliance.copy: We operate under Argentine National Law with official permits and an in-house fossil prep lab.
